The Croton-Harmon Union Free School District is pleased to announce that the 2020-21 budget presented to the community was overwhelmingly approved by a vote of 1687 YES votes and 487 NO votes. The budget of $49,424,525 is $500,000 below the allowable tax cap levy and less than a two percent increase over the prior year’s budget.

The community also approved a transportation proposition at a vote of 1252 YES and 885 NO which will allow the district to purchase three vehicles at an amount not to exceed $225,000.

We are also pleased to announce that the trustees chosen by voters are:

Sarah Carrier

Neal Haber

Beth McFadden

Finally, the Croton Free Library Proposition was also passed by a vote of 1712 YES votes and 419 NO votes.

Please see the message from Superintendent Dr. O'Connell

It's National Picnic Day!

A perfect follow-up to Earth Day, National Picnic Day encourages people to take their food outdoors to enjoy with family and friends. But if we're dodging rain drops today, we think that an indoor picnic can work just as well.

While picnics don't need to be anything fancy, they do have a rather illustrious history. During the early 19th century a group of wealthy London citizens formed “The Picnic Society” to promote picnics as social gatherings. These picnics were potlucks, and each participant also had to provide a share of the entertainment. The society members drank from crystal goblets and listened to a live string quartet while eating their meal!

So bring your favorite people and your favorite tunes and enjoy a picnic lunch or dinner today.

It is said that music soothes the soul. CET Music Teacher Marlena Horton believes that is true - and that music can be made anywhere.

Ms. Horton has challenged CET students to combine their love for music and passion for sustainability to create an instrument out of recycled materials. Have a look at the great creations n shared so far - Owen & Rory with guitars and MJ with percussion.

Ms Horton wants to remind students that music is all around them and that they do not need an expensive instrument to be a musician.

She says: "Having the students make their own instruments makes them think about how the instrument makes it sound, why it is in the family it is in and what materials make for the best instrument. I also feel it is important to reuse items to create them, it reinforces the idea of helping our environment and that trash can be a treasure."

The fourth grade at CET has been learning about the Chinese culture as the Chinese New Year is celebrated. To culminate the lesson, students treated the school to a colorful parade throughout the hallways, complete with a dragon and lanterns.

Chinese dragons are a symbol of China's culture, and they are believed to bring good luck to people. The dragons are believed to possess qualities that include great power, dignity, fertility, wisdom and auspiciousness.

The Chinese New Year holiday comes to its climax with the Yuan Xiao or Lantern Festival. Began over 2000 years ago, the festival celebrates family reunions and society and features ancient spiritual traditions.

Also, 2020 marks the Year of the Rat. The animal seen as a sign of wealth and surplus in Chinese culture.

Multiplying and dividing fractions, greatest common factor, simple and complex fractions - these are just a few of the many lessons when teaching fractions. Teachers often report that fractions are a difficult concept to grasp and, not surprisingly, it ends up being a one of students less-preferred units.

At PVC, teachers are tackling this issue by creating the Fraction Fair, an event for which sixth-graders team up to create carnival-style games that help explain concepts and draw people in to learn. It also gives students an opportunity to interact with those coming to their booth as they explain their idea.

Among the many creative ideas for games were ski ball, ping pong toss, duck shoot, and golf putting. The games determine which type of question you'll answer. Responses to questions are collected throughout the fair and correct answers are eligible for prizes. Who says math can't be fun?
